Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Situation2: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Story: Tonight, I sit on the edge of my bed, phone in hand, heart pounding. As a wife, I know my husband needs me—he’s been anxious all week about a major decision at work. He called earlier, voice trembling, asking if we could talk tonight. He needs my support, my advice, my presence. But as a girlfriend, I promised my partner we’d spend this one free evening together before she leaves for a week-long trip. She’s been looking forward to it, planning every detail, hoping we’d make memories to hold onto while she’s away. I can hear her laughter from the living room, waiting for me to join her. My husband’s text notification lights up my screen, a silent plea for comfort. My girlfriend’s playlist drifts through the apartment, a reminder of the night we planned. I feel torn, pulled in two directions by love and loyalty, expectations and needs. My chest tightens as I try to decide where I belong tonight, knowing I can’t be both places at once.
